FoldReducer#

class FoldReducer(foldfn: Callable[[Tensor, Tensor], Tensor], *, mapfn: OneToOne[Tensor] | ManyToOne[Tensor] | None = None, filterfn: Callable[[Tensor], bool] | None = None, initfn: OneToOne[Tensor] | None = None)[source]#

Bases: Reducer

Applies a function between the previously stored data and the new observation, merging the two.

Integration of new input follows the steps below.

  1. mapfn is applied to the inputs, returning a single tensor.

  2. filterfn is applied to the output of mapfn, returning a boolean value.

  3. foldfn is applied to the current state and the output of mapfn, if and only if the output of filterfn is true

  4. the current state is replaced with the output of foldfn, if and only if the output of filterfn is true

Parameters:

  • foldfn (Callable[[torch.Tensor, torch.Tensor], torch.Tensor]) – recurrence relation between the new input (left) and current state (right), returning the new state.

  • mapfn (OneToOne[torch.Tensor] | ManyToOne[torch.Tensor] | None, optional) – transformation to apply to inputs, no transformation if None. Defaults to None.

  • filterfn (Callable[[torch.Tensor], bool] | None, optional) – conditional test if transformed input should be integrated, always will if None. Defaults to None.

  • initfn (OneToOne[torch.Tensor] | None, optional) – function to return the initial state, when given the input tensor transformed by mapfn. Defaults to None.

Note

The lefthand argument of foldfn is the new input, and the righthand argument is the current state.

Note

The default mapfn implemented assumes only a single input, and will therefore fail if multiple input values are passed into forward().

Note

Output of foldfn is not passed through fitlerfn. Implementing a post-filter should be performed in foldfn itself.

clear() → None[source]#

Reinitializes the reducer’s state.

datato(*args, **kwargs)[source]#

Applies PyTorch to() function to storage tensor.

This directly calles torch.Tensor.to`() on the underlying tensor and replacing the pre-call tensor with this. It can be used to set non-float/non-complex datatypes.

peek() → Tensor | None[source]#

Returns the cumulative state from observations since the reducer was last cleared.

Returns:

accumulation of observations if any have been made, otherwise None.

Return type:

torch.Tensor | None

pop() → Tensor | None[source]#

Returns the cumulative state from observations and resets the reducer.

Returns:

cumulative state of recorded observations if any have been made,

otherwise None.

Return type:

torch.Tensor | None

push(*inputs: Tensor) → None[source]#

Incorporates inputs into the cumulative state.

Parameters:

inputs (torch.Tensor...) – data to incorporate into the current state.
